solution.text:
Let the number be y.
Add it to \( \frac_{j}__{k}_ \)
= \( \frac_{j}__{k}_ \) +y
Now multiply the above expression by _{l}_.
= (\( \frac_{j}__{k}_ \)+y) x _{l}_
The above expression is equal to 5 times of 1 more than the number i.e. 5(1+y)
Therefore,the equation is
(\(\frac_{j}__{k}_ \)+y) x _{l}_=5(1+y)
Opening the bracket in the LHS.
\( \frac_{j}__{k}_ \) x _{l}_+ _{l}_y = 5(1+y)
_{{j*l}}_/_{k}_+_{l}_y = 5+5y
_{{j*l}}_/_{k}_ -5 = (5-_{l}_)y
(_{{(j*l)}}_-_{{5*k}}_)/_{k}_ = (5-_{l}_)y
_{{(j*l)-(5*k)}}_/_{{(k*(5-l))}}_ = y
\( \Rightarrow \) y= _{{trunc(( (Decimal(j)*l) - (5*k) )/(k*(5-l)),2)}}_

content.text: Anjali adds a number to \( \frac_{j}__{k}_ \) and then multiplies it by _{l}_. The result is equal to 5 times of 1 more than the number. What is the value of the number? (Write upto 2 decimal places)
